facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 205 of 1956 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPFLLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 205 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated 30th November 1955 of Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 282 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 30th November, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 282 of 1955,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated 15th February 1955 of Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar in Sessions Case No. 64 of Trial No. 6 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 15th February, 1955, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar in Sessions Case No. 64 of Trial No. 6 of 1955.

facts.text: Appellant Bakshish Singh and brother Gurbakshi Singh tried for offence under ss. 302/34 IPC and acquitted by Additional Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Bakshish Singh and his brother Gurbakshi Singh were tried for an offence under ss. 302/34 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted.

facts.text: State appealed to High Court against acquittal; Gurbaksh Singh absconding so appeal against appellant alone heard and decided, reversing acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment the State took an appeal to the High Court. As Gurbaksh Singh was said to be ab- sconding the appeal against the appellant alone was heard and decided by the High Court.

facts.text: On August 1, 1954, between 7 and 8 p.m., Bachhinder Singh son of Bhagwan Singh of village Kairon shot in lane in front of their house.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1954, sometime between 7 and 8 p.m Bachhinder Singh son of Bhagwan Singh of village Kairon was shot in the lane in front of their house

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh died the next day in hospital at Amritsar due to bullet injuries.

anchor.surface_text: and as a result of bullet injuries be died the next day in the hospital at Amritsar.

facts.text: At time of shooting, Bachhinder Singh accompanied by younger brother Narvel Singh, a boy of 13.

anchor.surface_text: He was at the time of shooting accompanied by his younger brother Narvel Singh, a boy of 13,

facts.text: After injury, Bachhinder Singh and Narvel Singh returned to house; Bachhinder informed father Bhagwan Singh of identity of assailants.

anchor.surface_text: and after getting injured Bachhinder Singh and his brother returned to the house. Bhagwan Singh states that he was informed of the identity of the assailants by Bachhinder Singh

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh carried to hospital at Kairon at his request; doctor rendered first aid and advised to V.J. Hospital Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: who was, at his own request, carried from the house to the hospital at Kairon but as the injuries were serious the doctor at Kairon rendered first aid and advised the father to take his son to V. J. Hospital at Amritsar.

facts.text: Bhagwan Singh took Bachhinder to Railway Station; went to Police Post Kairon 100 yds away to report, ASI away at Sarhali.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwan Singh then took Bachhinder Singh to the Railway Station but before the arrival of the train he went to the Police Post at Kairon which is at a distance of about 100 yds. from the Railway Station in order to make a report. As the Assistant Sub Inspector was away at Sarhali,

facts.text: Returned to station, took son by train leaving Kairon at 9-47 p.m. to Amritsar hospital, accompanied by Narvel Singh PW12, Shamir Singh, Inder Singh, Narinjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: he returned to the Railway Station and took his son to the Amritsar hospital by the train leaving Kairon at 9-47 p.m. Bhagwan Singh was accompanied at that time by his younger son, Narvel Singh, P.W. 12, and by Shamir Singh, Inder Singh and Narinjan Singh.

facts.text: At Amritsar hospital, Bachhinder examined by Dr. Kanwal Kishore PW2 at 11-45 p.m., injury serious, sent info to police.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after their arrival at the Amritsar hospital Bachhinder Singh was examined by Dr. Kanwal Ki- shore, P.W. 2, at 11-45 p.m. and finding the injury to be of a serious nature the doctor sent information to the Police

facts.text: Head Constable Maya Ram Sharma PW4 arrived after midnight, in presence Dr. Mahavir Sud PW17 recorded dying declaration Ex P-H after fitness certificate.

anchor.surface_text: as a result of which Head Constable Maya Ram Sharma, P.W. 4, arrived at the hospital sometime after midnight and, in the presence of Dr. Mahavir Sud, P.W. 17, recorded the dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh, Exhibit P-H, after getting a certificate from the doctor that the injured person was in a fit state to make a statement.

facts.text: First Information Report Ex P-H/1 copy of Ex P-H, recorded 2 Aug 1954 at 7-50 a.m. at PS Sarhali, 20 miles from Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: This statement is the basis of the First Information Report, Exhibit P-H. 1, which is a companyy of Exhibit P-H. This report was recorded on August 2, 1954, at 7-50 a.m. at Police Station Sarhali which, we were told, is about 20 miles or so away from Amritsar.

facts.text: Early morning 2 Aug 1954, Dr. K.C. Saronwala PW1 operated on Bachhinder, extracted bullet from left abdominal wall, handed to police.

anchor.surface_text: In the early hours of the morning Dr. K. C. Saronwala P.W. I performed an operation on Bachhinder Singh and extracted a bullet from the left abdominal wall which was handed over to the Police.

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh died at 1-35 p.m. on 2 Aug 1954.

anchor.surface_text: But Bachhinder Singh died at 1-35 p.m. on August 2, 1954.

facts.text: Inquest report Ex P-K prepared at 2-30 p.m. by Head Constable Maya Ram PW4.

anchor.surface_text: An inquest report Exhibit P-K was prepared at 2-30 p.m. by Head Constable Maya Ram, P.W. 4.

facts.text: Narvel Singh PW12 was eyewitness to the occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: on the statement of Narvel Singh, P.W. 12, who was an eye witness to the occur- rence

facts.text: Bachhinder made statement to father Bhagwan Singh as to assailant soon after brought to house.

anchor.surface_text: and on the statement made by the deceased to his father as to his assailant as soon as he  Bachhinder Singh  was brought to the house after receiving the injuries.

facts.text: Extra-judicial confession to Teja Singh PW13 rejected by both courts below.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution also relied on an extra-judicial companyfession made to Teja Singh, P.W. 13, but both the companyrts below have rejected this piece of evidence and it is unnecessary to companysider it any further.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge rejected dying declaration Ex P-H on grounds that only father and brother present but police enquired from them first, and detailed form suggests touched up.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge rejected the dying declaration made by Bachhinder Singh on two grounds that at the time of recording the dying declaration number only Bhagwan Singh, the father, and Narvel Singh, the brother of Bachhin- der Singh, were present but the police officer had actually made enquiries from them about the occurrence before he proceeded to record the dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh de- ceased.

facts.text: Head Constable Maya Ram PW4 admitted in cross-exam that Bachhinder gave statement in Punjabi but recorded in detailed Urdu form.

anchor.surface_text: Head Constable Maya Ram, P.W. 4, has admitted in cross-examination that Bachhinder Singh gave his statement in Punjabi but the form and the detailed account given in the statement, Exhibit P-H, would show that it was number the product of Bachhinder Singhs creation alone but it was a touched up declaration of the deceased.

facts.text: Punjab High Court disagreed with trial court's criticism of dying declaration, accepted it as voluntary and authentic.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court did number agree with this criticism. Birhan Narain J., who delivered the main judg- ment, said This criticism appears to me to be without any substance. The statement was recorded by Head Constable Maya Ram who was posted in Amritsar and was number posted in village Kairon and therefore had numberknowledge of the parties number had any interest in them

facts.text: Dr. Mahavir Sud PW17 present during recording, testified voluntary, no prompting, no one else present.

anchor.surface_text: Throughout the time that the statement was recorded Dr. Mahavir Sud of the Amritsar hospital was present. He has appeared as P.W. 17 in the present case. He is a respectable and disinterested person and he is positive in his testimony before the companyrt that the statement was made by the deceased voluntarily and that there was numberody present to prompt him.

anchor.surface_text: under ss. 302/34 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted.

issues.text: Whether the dying declaration Exhibit P-H is voluntary, genuine and free from prompting or influence of interested persons?

anchor.surface_text: Head Constable Maya Ram, P.W. 4, has admitted in cross-examination that Bachhinder Singh gave his statement in Punjabi but the form and the detailed account given in the statement, Exhibit P-H, would show that it was not the product of Bachhinder Singhs creation alone but it was a touched up declaration of the deceased. It is laid down in 1954 Lahore 805 that a dying declaration which records the very words of the dying man unassisted by interested persons is most valuable evidence but the value of a dying declara- tion altogether disappears when parts of it had obviously been supplied to the dead man by other persons whether interested or Police Officer.

issues.text: Whether recording the dying declaration in Urdu when made in Punjabi renders it inadmissible or unreliable?

anchor.surface_text: Another reason given by the Additional Sessions Judge for rejecting the dying declaration was that the deceased gave the narrative of events in Punjabi and the statement was taken down in urdu. In the Punjab that is how the dying declarations are taken down and that has been so ever since the courts were established and judicial authority has never held that to be an infirmity in dying declarations making them inefficacious.

issues.text: Whether the dying declaration exceeds the permissible scope under Section 32(1) of the Evidence Act due to its detailed narrative?

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit P-H, the dying declaration, is a long document and is a narrative of a large number of incidents which happened before the actual assault. Such long statements which are more in the nature of First Information Reports than recital of the cause of death or circumstances resulting in it are likely to give the impression of their being not genuine or not having been made unaided and without prompting. The dying declaration is the statement made by a person as to the cause of his death or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death and such details which fall outside the ambit of this are not strictly within the permissible limits laid down by s. 32  1  of the Evi- dence Act

issues.text: Whether the conditions under Section 33 of the Evidence Act were complied with for admitting Dr. Mahavir Sud's previous statement?

anchor.surface_text: The admissibility of the statement of Dr. Mahavir Sud was assailed by counsel for the appellant on the ground that the conditions laid down for the admissibility of statements under s. 33 had not been complied with and several decided cases were relied upon. This question does not seem to have been raised at any previous stage of the proceedings, neither before the Additional Sessions Judge nor before the High Court, and this criticism seems to be without much substance.

issues.text: Whether corroboration is essential for the efficacy of the dying declaration?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel then contended that for the efficacy of the dying declaration, corroboration was essential. In the present case there is the statement of Narvel Singh, P. W. 12, who is an eye witness to the occurrence which is relied upon by the prosecution as corroboration of the dying declaration.

issues.text: Whether adverse inference can be drawn under Section 114 of the Evidence Act for non-production of witness Sucha Singh?

anchor.surface_text: The non-production of Sucha Singh who is stated in the dying declaration and in the statement of Narvel Singh, P.W. 12, to have witnessed the occurrence was commented upon by counsel as a very serious omission. The Public Prosecutor stated at the trial that he was giving up Sucha Singh as he had been won over. Therefore, if produced, Sucha Singh would have been no better than a suborned witness. ... No adverse inference under s. 114 of the Evidence Act can be drawn against the State.

issues.text: Whether the High Court correctly applied the principles governing appeals against acquittal?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in our opinion, have kept in view correct principles governing appeals against acquittals and have rightly applied them to the circumstances of this case. The erroneous view that the learned Sessions Judge took of the dying declaration and of the oral evidence were compelling enough reasons for the reversal of that judgment.

arguments.claim: Bhagwan Singh's testimony that deceased named assailants immediately after injury is reliable

anchor.surface_text: Besides Narvel Singh there is the statement of Bhagwan Singh, the father, who stated that as soon as Bachhinder Singh came into the house he mentioned the names of his assailants to him. The incident took place just outside the house of Bhagwan Singh and it was never disputed that he was present in the house when the incident took place.

holdings.text: The dying declaration recorded in the present case is a voluntary one and was made without any prompting from anybody; the High Court correctly appreciated the evidence and was right in accepting the authenticity of the dying declaration.

anchor.surface_text: I have no doubt in my mind that the dying decla- ration recorded in the present case is a voluntary one and was made without any prompting from anybody. The High Court in our opinion correctly appreciated the evidence and was right in accepting the authenticity of the dying declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Head Constable disinterested (posted in Amritsar, no local knowledge), Dr. Mahavir Sud present and testified voluntary with no prompting or others present; trial court's criticisms rejected as without substance.

holdings.text: Recording dying declaration in Urdu when given in Punjabi is standard practice in Punjab and not a ground for rejection.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court language is Urdu; police routinely record statements in Urdu even if made in Punjabi; longstanding practice never held infirm by judicial authority.

holdings.text: The dying declaration must be limited to cause of death or circumstances of transaction under s.32(1) Evidence Act; extraneous details should not be included unless necessary for coherence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Long narratives resembling FIRs may appear prompted; desirable to frame rules limiting scope, but judgment of authenticity per circumstances.

holdings.text: Statement of Dr. Mahavir Sud admissible under s.33 Evidence Act as conditions satisfied (witness unavailable without unreasonable delay/expense).
holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior objection; inquiries made, whereabouts unknown; prosecution showed unavailability.

holdings.text: Corroboration is not essential for the efficacy of a dying declaration.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Though not required, here corroborated by eyewitness Narvel Singh and father's testimony.

holdings.text: No adverse inference under s.114 Evidence Act for non-production of Sucha Singh, who was won over.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecutorial discretion not to call won-over witness who would be discredited; cites precedents (Abdul Mohammad, etc.).

holdings.text: High Court correctly applied principles governing appeals against acquittals in reversing the acquittal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge's erroneous view of dying declaration and oral evidence justified reversal.

holdings.text: High Court rightly held the dying declaration to be a statement made by the deceased unaided by any outside agency and without prompting.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the High Court rightly held the dying declaration to be a statement made by the deceased unaided by any outside agency and without prompting by anybody.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recorder satisfied fitness; no questions put suggesting prompting; doctor's evidence supports.

anchor.surface_text: I have no doubt in my mind that the dying decla- ration recorded in the present case is a voluntary one and was made without any prompting from anybody. The High Court in our opinion correctly appreciated the evidence and was right in accepting the authenticity of the dying declaration.

The High Court, in our opinion, have kept in view companyrect principles governing appeals against acquittals and have rightly applied them to the circumstances A.I.R. 1945 P.C. 42 A.I.R. 1936 P.C. 289.  3  1954 S.C.R. 475. of this case. The erroneous view that the learned Sessions Judge took of the dying declaration and of the oral evidence were companypelling enough reasons for the reversal of that judgment.
